title: Juan Ramon Jimenez - Nobel Prize in Literature, 1956 (9 books)
description:
JUAN RAMÃ“N JIMÃ‰NEZ (1881-1958) was a prolific Spanish poet and writer who received the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1956 "for his lyrical poetry, which in the Spanish language constitutes an example of high spirit and artistical purity."

An early twentieth century pioneer in the use of free verse, JimÃ©nez was hailed by The New Republic as "not only the dean of Hispanic poets, but the pioneer and the source of all those who wrote in the Spanish tongue after him."  While his early poetry was influenced by the French Symbolists and W.B. Yeats, his later work shows an interest in stark imagery, colors, and the open forms associated with "naked" poetry.

Although he was primarily a poet, JimÃ©nez' prose work PLATERO AND I (1917), about a writer and his donkey, sold well in Latin America and in translation won him popularity in the U.S.  The little donkey remains a symbol of tenderness, purity and naivete, and is used by the author as a means of reflection about the simple joys of life, memories, and description of characters and their ways of life.


The following books are in PDF format unless otherwise noted:

* Animal de fondo [Animal at Bottom] (Nobel Prize Library, 1971).  Translated by Eloise Roach.

* Complete Perfectionist, The: A Poetics of Work (Doubleday, 1997).  Edited and translated by Christopber Maurer.

* Fifty Spanish Poems (Dolphin, 1950).  Bilingual Spanish/English edition.  Translated by J. B. Trend.

* Nobel Acceptance Speech (Nobel Prize Library, 1971).

* Platero and I (Signet Classics, 1960).  Translated by William H. and Mary M. Roberts.  Illustrated by Baltasar Lobo.

* Platero and I (Nobel Prize Library, 1971).  Translated by Eloise Roach.

* Selected Poems of Lorca and JimÃ©nez (Beacon, 1973).  Bilingual Spanish/English edition.  Translated by Robert Bly.

* Selected Writings of Juan RamÃ³n JimÃ©nez (Farrar Straus & Cudahy, 1957).  Edited by Eugenio Florit; translated by H. R. Hays.

* Time and Space : A Poetic Autobiography (toExcel, 2000).  Translated by Antonio T. de NicolÃ¡s. -- ePUB
